overview.short: Legionella miceadei is a Gram-negative aerobic rod that can cause pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised patients.
overview.clinical_context: Less common cause of Legionella infection; often requires molecular methods for definitive identification.

species_markers.notes: Gelatin negativity can help separate L. miceadei from L. pneumophila when paired with other evidence.
Urinary antigen is typically negative for nonâ€“L. pneumophila serogroup 1 infections.
Species-level confirmation is typically molecular due to overlapping phenotypes within Legionella.

common_confusions.reason: Both require BCYE and share many biochemical negatives; pneumophila is more likely clinically but not guaranteed.
Similar profile; differentiation is frequently not robust via basic bench biochemistry.

when_to_question_identification: Strong gelatin positivity supports L. pneumophila over L. miceadei.
Positive urinary antigen strongly favors L. pneumophila serogroup 1.
Growth on standard media argues against Legionella.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Most practical route to confirm non-pneumophila species.
Useful where Legionella library coverage is strong and the organism is cultured on BCYE.
If positive, supports L. pneumophila serogroup 1 over L. miceadei.
